msContents.summary: ff.2 recto-283 verso Octateuch: 1) 2 recto-56 verso = Genesis. 2) 57 recto-98 verso = Exodus. 3) 99 recto-138 recto = Leviticus. 4) 138 verso-189 verso = Numbers. 5) 190 recto-228 recto = Deuteronomy. 6) 228 verso-253 verso = Joshua. 7) 254 recto-280 recto = Judges. 8) 280 verso-283 verso = Ruth.

handDesc.handNote: hand of notes and verse numbers

item.desc: 1) f.1 recto contains the CMS stamp, some geometric patterns, ‘In the name of the Father...’ in Geez, and notes in at least 3 hands, in Latin, concerning the contents of the volume. 2) f.1 verso contains a design of 5 columns of 8 circles each, surrounded by a haräg in green, red, and yellow, with a blue cross near the centre. The first 28 circles contain, reading in order downwards, a fragment concerning Adam and Seth, from book I of the Ethiopic Qälemantos. 3) f. 2 recto bears, in red, the Ethiopic hearing ‘Orit Zälddät’ and in black the Latin ‘LIBEGNESIS’ (sic); also the (? Amharic) instruction bäm[?]hl[?]la bä[?]atä k[?]rämt anb[?]b, continuing (in Geez) ‘and on Monday morning’. 4) Chapter numbers and verse numbers have been marked, in a later hand, from Genesis 1(1)-Joshua 4(7), and in Ruth; in the remainder of Joshua and Judges, most chapter numbers are marked. [There follows, in the printed catalogue, a table entitled ‘Comparison of Ethiopic Manuscripts Numbers’]. 5) The text is frequently corrected, in places in the hand that marked the verses. 6) There is an Arabic note in the space between the columns on f.3 verso. 7) ff.7 recto-verso and 8 recto (paper, not parchment) contain the text of Genesis 4(15)-6(10) in, apparently, the same hand as the rest of the MS. On 8 verso there is a crude drawing, a prayer for one Bähaylä s[?]llus and (upside down) a false start by the scribe on Genesis 4(15). 8) f.56 verso has a picture of an eagle. 9) ff.67 recto, 72 recto, 74 verso, 75 recto and passim have further instructions about the times when passages are to be read, and the text (e.g. f.75 recto) contains red marks, possibly markers for these lections, the first a combination of the Geez letters z[?] and yä, the second a combination of the letters qw[?] and m[?] (possibly representing [?]mz[?]yyä and qw[?]t[?]r and m[??]draf. 10) f.98 verso has a crude drawing. 11) On f.167 recto, a major dittography has been indicated by the hand that numbered the verses. 12) f.189 verso bears an illiterate note. 13) f.204 verso has a härag, coloured yellow. 14) f.228 recto has a note ‘Which God spoke to Moses’, 570, which was numbered (i.e. God’s commands to Moses were 570), forgive your servant ‘Y[?]shaq’. 15) The margin of f.253 recto, against the LXX end of Joshua (following Heb. Josh. 24(33)) has [?]mz[?] ihallo bä[??]bray y[?]be märqor[?]yos’, ‘From here is not in Hebrew, says Märqo[?]yos’. No doubt this is the same Märqo[?]yos who annotated the MS of Job edited by F.M. Esteves Pereira (‘Patrologia Orientalis, 1907 and see also E. Ullendorf, ‘Ethiopia and the Bible’, pp.42-43). 16) f.253 verso has a note in two different hands, first a list of books and church property of Betä Yohann[?]s and M[?]qwamä Maryam, and continuing ‘This is the matter which happened by reason of the custodian among the pilgrims, who is named Täklä Wäld’, after which the list of books and church property is repeated, with slight alterations. 17) f.282 recto has a note, almost erased, ‘Remember, O Lord, poor Y[?]shaq’. 18) f.283 verso has a note ‘Pray for us who laboured on this book and for Y[?]shaq your servant who gave this to holy Jerusalem’, and on f.284 recto, beneath a prayer in Arabic, the note begins ‘lest our enemies say to us...’. Beneath this, with the letters left white on an inked background, is ‘I poor Y[?]shaq; by your prayer it was completed in the house of the gäbäz of Aksum (betä gäbäzä Aksum); I trusted in your name, O Lord, that you would not put me in any place other than the land of Zion, the land of Christ, the church, and do not forget me, in your prayer, you who read and hear’. This continues on f. 284 verso with blank ink on white parchment ‘Accept, O Lord, this gift, for me, your poor servant, and accept all the books which I brought so that the brothers who are living in Jerusalem might take heart and pray for me...’. It continues "wäsä[?]atani lä[?]akku läk[?]mu qädami zä[?]itäs[?]hfä amä n[?]fäqq[?]d zäwähäbku habä gädlä säma[??]t s[?]räyu wäbar[?]ku wä[?]adi läbarya zena abäw wäläqw[?]sqwam nägäst lädäqiqä habasi kämä y[?]tnazäzu. Wä[??]mmässä gäb[?]u b[?]hernä wä[?]adi fäläsu w[?]stä kal[?] b[?]her yagb[??]u lä[?]iyärusalem läqäranyu...". 19) f.285 recto bears a picture of ‘Our Father Peter’, and 285 verso of ‘The apostle Andrew’. 20) f.286 is a hand-written document in Latin, cut at the top and used for binding.

binding.decoNote: European leather binding ; paper used for guard leaves
The binding bears the initials C.M.S. (i.e. Church Missionary Society) and on the spin is ‘MSS AETHIOP. PENTAHEU: CUM LIB. IOSUE. IUDICUM ET RUTH MDCXCVI.’

history.provenance:
The ms. was written in Aksum and presented by to the Ethiopian community in Jerusalem. From there it passed to Rome together with other mss. and, having been transferred from the hostel of San Stefano dei Mori to the Museo Borgiano, it was stolen and brought to London.
In 1817 the bookseller J. Smith in Drury Lane sold it to Church Missionary Society, which transferred it to the British and Foreign Bible Society, for use in a printed Ethiopic edition.
